properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight through Saturday morning. What: Snow squalls. Reduced visibilities in heavy snow with local amounts of 10 to 15 cm. Some areas may approach 20 cm, especially over higher terrain. Where: Areas south of Georgian Bay. The heaviest snowfall amounts are expected to remain west of Barrie. When: 8 P.M. tonight until noon Saturday. Discussion: Snow squalls have developed off Georgian Bay this evening and will weaken around the noon hour on Saturday. The axis of the snow squalls will set up west of Highway 400, however, periods of heavy snow will be possible on Highway 400 south of Barrie, particularly Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-06T18:10:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-06T02:11:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2512690863.2021
Area: Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow Squalls possible tonight through Saturday morning. What: Snow squalls. Reduced visibilities in heavy snow with locally heavy amounts possibly reaching 15 cm. Where: Southern Dufferin County east to Cookstown. When: 9 P.M. tonight until noon Saturday. Discussion: Snow squalls will develop off Georgian Bay this evening. This area continues to be monitored for a possible upgrade to Snow Squall Warning. The axis of the snow squalls will set up west of Highway 400, however, periods of heavy snow will be possible on Highway 400 south of Barrie, particularly Saturday morning. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-06T13:53:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-05T21:54:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2441195597.2021
Area: Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VERNON (March 3, 2021 - Vernon) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Vernon because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-06T15:06:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-05T23:07:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0309261597.2021
Area: North Okanagan
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are possible this weekend for Naujaat and Coral Harbour. As a low pressure system approaches the Kivalliq region from the west on Saturday an area of snow and strong southerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will likely produce blizzard conditions beginning Sunday morning. Conditions will likely first deteriorate in Naujaat beginning Saturday overnight before affecting Coral Harbour on Sunday. Visibilities should improve by Monday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-06T12:37:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-05T20:38:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1634591296.2021
Area: Naujaat, Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are possible this weekend in portions of the Kivalliq region. As a low pressure system approaches the Kivalliq region from the west late Friday night, an area of snow and strong southerly winds gusting from 60 to 80 km/h will likely produce blizzard conditions beginning Saturday morning. Conditions will likely first deteriorate in Baker Lake and Arviat beginning Saturday morning before affecting the communities of Rankin Inlet and Chesterfield Inlet by Saturday afternoon. Visibilities could improve as soon as Saturday night in Baker Lake but will likely remain poor in the remaining coastal communities until Sunday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-06T07:35:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-05T15:36:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0336650858.2021
Area: Baker Lake, Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain will continue tonight in Northern Alberta. A band of freezing rain developed near High Level this evening. Patchy freezing rain will continue in the area until after midnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-06T11:02:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-06T03:56:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3847048199.2021

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Northwesterly winds will cause blowing snow tonight over communities located along the coast of James Bay. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-06T12:41:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-05T20:42:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2073248071.2021
Area: Waskaganish, James Bay and La Grande River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

Brisk northwesterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will combine with falling snow to create areas of poor visibility in blowing snow, especially along the shores of James Bay and in open areas. properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow Saturday night and Sunday in Resolute. Strong winds and falling snow will combine to reduce the visibility in blowing snow by Saturday afternoon. By the evening hours visibility may degrade to below 400 m bringing blizzard conditions to the area. Poor visibility will persist through the night and much of Sunday. This alert may be upgraded to a blizzard warning as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
